title.text: ENHANCING EXPLANATION COHERENCE WITH RHETORICAL STRATEGIES

entities.text: ENHANCING EXPLANATION COHERENCE WITH RHETORICAL STRATEGIES

abstractContent.text: This paper discusses the application of a previously reported theory of explanation rhetoric (Maybury, 1988b) to the task of explaining constraint violations in a hybrid rule/frame based system for resource allocation (Dawson et al, 1987).

This research illustrates how discourse strategies of explanation, textual connectives, and additional justification knowledge can be applied to enhance the cohesiveness, structure, and clarity of knowledge based system explanations.

introductionContent.text: Recent work in text generation includes emphasis on producing textual presentations of the explanations of reasoning in knowledge-based systems.

Initial work on the direct translation of underlying system knowledge led to insights that more perspicuous justifications would result from keeping track of the principles or deep causal models which supported that knowledge.
And experiments with discourse strategies demonstrated the efficacy of the rhetorical organization of knowledge to produce descriptions, comparisons and clarification.
Researchers have recently observed) that the line of explanation should not isomorphically mirror the underlying line of reasoning as this often resulted in poorly connected text.
Others have attempted to classify patterns of explanations.

The approach presented here is to exploit generic explanation strategies and focus models to organize the back-end justification via an explanation rhetoric --that is, a rhetorical model of strategies that humans employ to persuade, support, or clarify their position.
The result is a more connected, flowing and thus easier to follow textual presentation of the explanation.
